awd_titl_txt: Conference: Advancing research and education in big data neuroscience
awd_abstract_narration:
NSF Conference Award: PI – Dr. Sharlene Newman, University of Alabama Tuscaloosa; Title: Advancing research and education in big data neuroscience

In recent years, there has been a massive increase in the number of publicly available neuroimaging datasets and online tools for their analysis. These developments have led to vastly productive research that makes use of existing data rather than incurring the cost of continuously creating new datasets. Online data sharing and analysis have also proved to be extremely beneficial to the transparency and accessibility of neuroscience to other communities (e.g., computational modelling, engineering). However, the benefits have not spread evenly, and remain concentrated in well-resourced labs and institutions. 

This workshop seeks to change that, by specifically engaging with less well-funding institutions across the South, particularly HBCUs, to provide training in the use of these tools, foster collaborations, and solicit insights from researchers at these institutions for how to further lower barriers to their participation. Participants will be provided with funding for travel to attend and participate in a multiday workshop consisting of talks, listening sessions, and direct training. Speakers and presenters include faculty from universities across the south and several HBCUs. The workshop aims to foster the development of a community of neuroimaging researchers across the South.

This project is jointly funded by Cognitive Neuroscience and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Motivation

The Advanced Computational Neuroscience Network (ACNN; neurosciencenetwork.org) held its Southern region meeting on September 27-29, 2023. The workshop continued the success of the previous year’s workshops that were seed-funded via the NSF Big Data program. The first meeting in the south was at the University of Texas in Austin hosted by Dr. Franco Pestilli in September 2022.

These following goals were achieved by the 2023 workshop:

  • Collaboration: Expand ACCN in the southern states and connect established and upcoming neuroscience research and training centers. Researchers and students from across the south were in attendance. They learned from each other and shared their ongoing research as well as discussed future collaborations. For example, Dr. Chris Rorden from the University of South Carolina’s group was in attendance and was able to provide valuable support to a junior research scientist who is beginning her development of a cohort of stroke patients in rural Alabama.  
  • Training: We hosted a 2-day intensive workshop targeting advanced undergraduate and graduate students focused on the use of brainlife.io to perform basic data management, MRI data preprocessing, and morphological analysis of structural data. The brainlife.io team conducted the hands-on workshop.
  • Increase Diversity: We invited faculty and students from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and other minority-serving institutions as well as limited resource institutions to the 2023 meeting. We engaged in outreach to several universities and had students from Alabama State University, Alabama A&M University, Tuskegee University and Stillman College register for the meeting, demonstrating the interest. We also had a faculty member from Alabama State University participate in the program, Dr. D. Lisa Cothran. Her involvement has led to a training grant application with The University of Alabama designed to train students in cognitive neuroscience research.

Program Committee and Program

  • Sharlene Newman, Professor of Psychology, Executive Director, Alabama Life Research Institute, University of Alabama 
  • Franco Pestilli, Associate Professor in the Department of Psychology at the University of Texas, Austin
  • Josiah Leong, Assistant Professor of Psychological Science, University of Arkansas
  • Kristina Visscher, Associate Professor, UAB Department of Neurobiology, Co-Director, Civitan International Neuroimaging Laboratory
  • Firat Soylu, Associate Professor, College of Education, University of Alabama
  • Jennifer Robinson, Associate Professor, Auburn University

The program is included in the appendix.

Recruitment and Participation

We advertised the workshop at colleges and universities across the southeast. Personal invitations were extended to faculty at HBCUs.

The list of registrants are in the appendix.

Session Summaries

September 27-28 – The brainlife.io workshop included the basics of MRI data and analyses followed by hands-on tutorials of brainlife.io. Participants learned how to upload and manage data in the environment and how to perform basic analyses.

Angela Laird gave a session on the use of the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study data. She provided an overview of the study and its goals, the available data, and how to access it. She also discussed responsible conduct of research with large, open datasets with a focus on preventing stigmatizing marginalized populations.

Olaf Sporns gave a session on connectomics. He provided an overview of the theory and application.

James Booth's research focuses on understanding the brain mechanisms of the development of language, reading and related cognitive processes in typical and atypical populations. He discussed his experience creating a large, open access dataset and some of the important considerations.

Marshall Abrams is a philosopher of science. He provided a session about the philosophical issues concerning the roles of uncertainty, unpredictability, and probability in neural processes.

We had two panel discussions:

  • Increasing diversity in cognitive neuroscience with Drs. Cothran, Newman and Pestilli. They discussed the interest and need for more extensive outreach to HBCUs, both faculty and students. At the same time it is important for there to be greater understanding of the different expectations of the faculty at primarily teaching institutions. There was also discussion about the importance of including diverse perspectives in cognitive neuroscience research and the impact those voices have on the interpretation of results.
  • Incorporating cognitive neuroscience methods in the classroom with brainlife.io with Drs. Delogu and Soylu. The panel discussed their experiences using brainlife.io in the classroom including student experiences.

Conclusions and Final Recommendation

In conclusion, the 2023 ACNN South meeting was an overall success. There was great participation. We had a range of participants - from undergraduates to graduate students to faculty – from multiple universities. There were plans made to host the next meeting at the University of Arkansas. Including a diverse group of participants was reported to lead to great conversations about both science and outreach to under-resourced colleges. 

It is recommended that more extensive outreach to under-resourced colleges and universities be performed. The students and faculty are interested in cognitive neuroscience and providing them an opportunity to engage would benefit science.
